description: The Cisco Certified Entry Networking Technician (CCENT) certification is targeted towards IT workers interested in becoming Network Administrators. The certification covers foundational networking topics required of anyone working with IPv4 and IPv6 networks. The series also covers configuring and maintaining Cisco routers and switches in small to medium sized networks. Topics covered in this series include routing protocols, VLANs, device security and more.
name: CCENT
subtitle: Cisco Certified Entry Networking Technician

episodes.description: The Cisco Certified Entry Networking Technician (CCENT) certification is targeted towards IT workers interested in becoming Network Administrators. The certification covers foundational networking topics required of anyone working with IPv4 and IPv6 networks. The series also covers configuring and maintaining Cisco routers and switches in small to medium sized networks. Topics covered in this series include routing protocols, VLANs, device security and more.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:08.763
[SOUND].

2
00:00:08.763 --> 00:00:12.547
In this video we're gonna take a look
at the Cisco certified entry network

3
00:00:12.547 --> 00:00:16.330
technician certification
show right here on ITPro.TV.

4
00:00:16.330 --> 00:00:18.860
First off, let's talk a little
bit about the certification.

5
00:00:18.860 --> 00:00:21.760
The CCENT is designed
to be your first step

6
00:00:21.760 --> 00:00:25.640
on the path to becoming a Cisco
certified network administrator.

7
00:00:25.640 --> 00:00:30.130
That this is designed for people who had
no work with Cisco who came up before.

8
00:00:30.130 --> 00:00:33.770
You may have never touched
a Cisco router or switch.

9
00:00:33.770 --> 00:00:35.890
Maybe you never even seen them.

10
00:00:35.890 --> 00:00:39.820
We start from the very basics and walk you
through, getting that first device set up.

11
00:00:39.820 --> 00:00:42.780
How do you get it out of the box, get
it turned on, and get it doing its job?

12
00:00:42.780 --> 00:00:45.590
And then what are some of
the advanced features?

13
00:00:45.590 --> 00:00:48.405
CCENT is absolutely
starting with the basics.

14
00:00:48.405 --> 00:00:52.765
We focus on one router, or one switch,
versus things like the CCNA,

15
00:00:52.765 --> 00:00:54.885
that's more like ten routers and
ten switches.

16
00:00:54.885 --> 00:00:58.385
Or the CCNP where it's hundreds of
routers or hundreds of switches.

17
00:00:58.385 --> 00:01:00.815
It gets progressively more complex.

18
00:01:00.815 --> 00:01:03.760
So, CCENT is that beginning part.

19
00:01:03.760 --> 00:01:05.045
This certification is designed for

20
00:01:05.045 --> 00:01:09.485
people who are, maybe you want to
become a network administrator, right?

21
00:01:09.485 --> 00:01:13.880
Cisco is the most Common network
manufacturer out there in the enterprise

22
00:01:13.880 --> 00:01:16.720
marketplace, you're gonna see
it in a lot of job requirements.

23
00:01:16.720 --> 00:01:19.450
So if you're wanting to get started,
maybe you're already an IT and

24
00:01:19.450 --> 00:01:22.960
you're supporting servers and you wanna
start moving over to the network side.

25
00:01:22.960 --> 00:01:24.902
Or maybe you're one of those
jack of all trades and

26
00:01:24.902 --> 00:01:27.725
you've been tasked with supporting
servers and switches and routers,

27
00:01:27.725 --> 00:01:29.402
you've got the whole thing on your plate.

28
00:01:29.402 --> 00:01:31.740
Well, Cisco's a great one to learn.

29
00:01:31.740 --> 00:01:35.040
There's other vendors that are out
there like HP and Juniper and

30
00:01:35.040 --> 00:01:38.970
they make great equipment but Cisco
really is the market leader in this area.

31
00:01:38.970 --> 00:01:40.538
So if you learn their equipment,

32
00:01:40.538 --> 00:01:43.344
the odds are you'll be able
to support most environments.

33
00:01:43.344 --> 00:01:47.355
And the technologies are really kind of
common between a lot of the vendors so

34
00:01:47.355 --> 00:01:48.502
we see that here too.

35
00:01:48.502 --> 00:01:51.891
Now CCENT does overlap a bit
with CompTIA's Network+, so

36
00:01:51.891 --> 00:01:54.547
if you've already done that certification.

37
00:01:54.547 --> 00:01:58.240
Some of it will be overlapped because we
do cover some fundamentals in theories.

38
00:01:58.240 --> 00:02:00.900
Let's take a look at
the exam itself real quick.

39
00:02:00.900 --> 00:02:05.131
So like I mentioned, CCNT is that
starting point on your Cisco Careers.

40
00:02:05.131 --> 00:02:09.046
So CCNA being the next step, that's
the Cisco Certified Network Associate and

41
00:02:09.046 --> 00:02:12.530
then Cisco Certified Network Professional
beyond that.

42
00:02:12.530 --> 00:02:16.819
The exam itself, it is one exam and
one certification.

43
00:02:16.819 --> 00:02:22.736
So you'll take the 100-105 which
is the version 3.0 of the CCENT.

44
00:02:22.736 --> 00:02:25.525
The exam itself is actually
called the interconnecting

45
00:02:25.525 --> 00:02:27.312
Cisco Network Devices Part I exam.

46
00:02:27.312 --> 00:02:31.320
The CCNA exam is the interconnecting
Cisco Network Devices Part 2 exam.

47
00:02:31.320 --> 00:02:34.380
You have to pass both to get your CCNA.

48
00:02:34.380 --> 00:02:37.194
You just to have pass this
one to get your CCENT.

49
00:02:37.194 --> 00:02:41.220
The exam itself covers
network fundamentals.

50
00:02:41.220 --> 00:02:42.970
Right, that's that overlap with Network+.

51
00:02:42.970 --> 00:02:46.610
We're gonna talk about IP addressing,
and Ethernet networks, and

52
00:02:46.610 --> 00:02:49.270
wireless networks, and
how these networks function.

53
00:02:49.270 --> 00:02:51.380
Then we get into LAN
switching fundamentals,

54
00:02:51.380 --> 00:02:53.330
which is really Cisco switches.

55
00:02:53.330 --> 00:02:54.820
So how does Cisco switches work?

56
00:02:54.820 --> 00:02:55.810
How do we configure them?

57
00:02:55.810 --> 00:02:58.050
How do we use technologies like VLANs?

58
00:02:58.050 --> 00:02:59.700
How do we implement them?

59
00:02:59.700 --> 00:03:01.150
Then we get into routing fundamentals.

60
00:03:01.150 --> 00:03:02.010
How do routers work?

61
00:03:02.010 --> 00:03:03.580
How do you set up a router, initially?

62
00:03:03.580 --> 00:03:07.060
How do you use dynamic routing protocols,
and static routing protocols.

63
00:03:07.060 --> 00:03:09.350
How do they make the decisions they make?

64
00:03:09.350 --> 00:03:10.710
Then we get into infrastructure service.

65
00:03:10.710 --> 00:03:12.700
This is probably the one
I have the most fun with.

66
00:03:12.700 --> 00:03:17.990
Because Cisco routers and switches can
do way more than just route and switch.

67
00:03:17.990 --> 00:03:20.490
And so we look at the advanced
functionality that's built into them.

68
00:03:20.490 --> 00:03:22.410
The stuff that's turned off by default.

69
00:03:22.410 --> 00:03:23.565
And we learn how to turn it on and

70
00:03:23.565 --> 00:03:26.332
actually make use of all that hardware
that we just paid so much money for.

71
00:03:26.332 --> 00:03:29.080
And then lastly we talked about
infrastructure maintenance.

72
00:03:29.080 --> 00:03:30.780
Once you've got your routers and
switches configured,

73
00:03:30.780 --> 00:03:32.140
you can't just forget about them.

74
00:03:32.140 --> 00:03:34.850
There's routine maintenance that we need
to do to keep them up and running and

75
00:03:34.850 --> 00:03:37.500
healthy, make sure they're patched for
security purposes and

76
00:03:37.500 --> 00:03:39.050
troubleshoot any issues that come up.

77
00:03:39.050 --> 00:03:41.970
That's all covered right there in the end.

78
00:03:41.970 --> 00:03:45.995
Now, one of the really cool parts
about the CCENT is, it is a great

79
00:03:45.995 --> 00:03:50.650
stepping-stone, it's that first step to
getting into Cisco Certification Network.

80
00:03:50.650 --> 00:03:53.330
And, it's also a multi-purpose cert.

81
00:03:53.330 --> 00:03:58.288
It used to be that CCENT matched up
with the CCNA for routing and switching,

82
00:03:58.288 --> 00:04:02.947
but now CCENT is actually a requirement
for several different CCNAs.

83
00:04:02.947 --> 00:04:05.590
You might continue on with
CCNA routing and switching.

84
00:04:05.590 --> 00:04:09.440
Or you might do CCNA security or
CCNA wireless.

85
00:04:09.440 --> 00:04:12.700
The CCENT exam is the same for
all of them.

86
00:04:12.700 --> 00:04:16.202
So, once you've passed your CCNA,
you're ready to move into any.

87
00:04:16.202 --> 00:04:18.450
I'm sorry, once you've passed your CCENT,

88
00:04:18.450 --> 00:04:21.970
you are ready to move into any of
the CCNA's that are out there.

89
00:04:21.970 --> 00:04:25.880
And you'll see there's CCNA Cloud,
Collaboration, Cyber Ops, Data Center,

90
00:04:25.880 --> 00:04:30.630
Industrial, Routing and Switching,
Security, Wireless, Service Provider.

91
00:04:30.630 --> 00:04:33.310
All these different ones,
CCENT is a requirement for them.

92
00:04:33.310 --> 00:04:37.640
So definitely a great place to get
started on your certification career.

93
00:04:37.640 --> 00:04:39.180
Now when you're ready to take the exam,

94
00:04:39.180 --> 00:04:41.140
the exam is actually administered
through Pearson Vue.

95
00:04:41.140 --> 00:04:42.550
You can go to the website,

96
00:04:42.550 --> 00:04:46.570
it's vue.com and
you can locate a testing center near you.

97
00:04:46.570 --> 00:04:48.790
They're located all over the world.

98
00:04:48.790 --> 00:04:52.930
And so you can sign up through Vue,
go and take the exam, pass it and

99
00:04:52.930 --> 00:04:55.190
get your CCENT certification.

100
00:04:55.190 --> 00:04:58.060
Now throughout our series, we're gonna
be covering all the exam objectives for

101
00:04:58.060 --> 00:04:59.240
that exam.

102
00:04:59.240 --> 00:05:02.750
Once you get in there, you start working
with the system, you get used to it.

103
00:05:02.750 --> 00:05:05.560
You jump in, you pass the test,
you get the certification and

104
00:05:05.560 --> 00:05:09.390
it's on your resume and you just started
your journey in the networking world.

105
00:05:09.390 --> 00:05:12.878
Another thing that I wanna mention here
real quick in the overview is that

106
00:05:12.878 --> 00:05:16.776
if you're just getting started, you might
not have access to Cisco equipment.

107
00:05:16.776 --> 00:05:18.600
I'm gonna show you all sorts
of things in this show.

108
00:05:18.600 --> 00:05:20.440
We'll see how to configure,
how the commands work,

109
00:05:20.440 --> 00:05:24.752
but there's no substitute for actually
getting exposure to real equipment.

110
00:05:24.752 --> 00:05:27.760
Well, on the ITPro.TV website,
if you take a look,

111
00:05:27.760 --> 00:05:29.850
we have what are called our advanced labs.

112
00:05:29.850 --> 00:05:30.950
They're not our regular labs.

113
00:05:30.950 --> 00:05:32.210
They are advanced labs.

114
00:05:32.210 --> 00:05:34.880
Instead of having a virtual
environment like our normal labs,

115
00:05:34.880 --> 00:05:38.090
our advanced labs give you access
to real physical equipment.

116
00:05:38.090 --> 00:05:41.630
We have a data center that's over in
London, you'll be able to connect in and

117
00:05:41.630 --> 00:05:44.450
remotely access those devices.

118
00:05:44.450 --> 00:05:47.220
It's priced at, I believe,
somewhere around $50 a year, so

119
00:05:47.220 --> 00:05:48.850
it's extremely inexpensive.

120
00:05:48.850 --> 00:05:52.440
And that gives you access to multiple
routers and multiple switches,

121
00:05:52.440 --> 00:05:56.530
not simulated ones, actual real
routers that you can work with any

122
00:05:56.530 --> 00:06:00.670
time you want throughout the day, 7 days
a week, 365 days a year, it's available.

123
00:06:00.670 --> 00:06:04.740
There's step by step labs you can go
through to try the technologies out and

124
00:06:04.740 --> 00:06:06.720
learn, and really see that.

125
00:06:06.720 --> 00:06:09.200
As you watch the show, you'll see
where even I use the advanced labs.

126
00:06:09.200 --> 00:06:11.930
In some of the episodes,
I use real equipment too.

127
00:06:11.930 --> 00:06:15.640
Real equipment is nice to just go on
eBay and buy some used equipment, and

128
00:06:15.640 --> 00:06:17.588
you can test and experiment and use it.

129
00:06:17.588 --> 00:06:19.430
You wouldn't wanna use it in production,
but for

130
00:06:19.430 --> 00:06:21.370
a home lab you can really learn
everything you need to know.

131
00:06:21.370 --> 00:06:24.030
So definitely get some hands on exposure.

132
00:06:24.030 --> 00:06:25.820
Watch our shows,
we cover the technologies there.

133
00:06:25.820 --> 00:06:27.660
And when you do both, you're ready.

134
00:06:27.660 --> 00:06:31.560
You're gonna pass the exam, get that
CCENT, and launch your certification.

135
00:06:31.560 --> 00:06:33.770
So if that sounds exciting to you,
you're definitely in the right place.

136
00:06:33.770 --> 00:06:37.670
Stay tuned,
we got CCENT episodes coming up.

137
00:06:37.670 --> 00:06:46.649
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don review the basic concepts of the 7 layer OSI networking model.  They briefly talk about it’s origins and then describe each of the 7 layers and how they function in networking.  Also, they describe the process of encapsulation and decapsulation and remind us that data is named differently at the Transport, Network, Data Link and Physical layers.
episodes.title: The OSI Model

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don review the TCP/IP protocol stack and its model.  They take the time to differentiate between TCP and UDP connections.  These difference are normally described as “guaranteed delivery” and “best effort, respectively, according to the guys.  They take a moment to also describe windowing and MTUs.
episodes.title: TCP/IP

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don provide a refresher on IPv4 addressing.  They introduce the concepts of an IP address and it’s purpose.  They also show the breakdown of the address into the network and host portions of the address to indicate how devices are recognized as being on the same network or different networks. The guys also do a run down of the glassful addressing scheme, demonstrating how it has changed by using subnet masks too.
episodes.title: Understanding IPv4

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don continue to help us to understand how IP addresses are used in delivering data.  They show the data delivery process using IP addresses and MAC addresses.  They guys take the time to review how to identify ip addresses that are on the same network too.   At the end they mention that Private IP addresses and their ranges that are used internally and not on the internet to help provide the number of IP addresses that companies may use without having to register the addresses with the IANA.
episodes.title: Understanding IPv4 Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don review the IPv6 concepts found in CCENT exam objectives.  They explain the fundamental improvements included in IPv6 include IPSec, QoS and even other protocols that currently require an addition to IPv4.  But the major improvements deals with the address space size and IP Mobility are key features for most networks, according to the guys.  Don then reviews the most common format of IPv6 addresses and the different types of IPv6 addresses you will encounter in IPv6 networks.
episodes.title: Understanding IPv6

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don introduce the major products that a CEENT will likely encounter in production.  They mainly focus in on Routers and Switches and mention the Cisco ASA (Firewall Appliance).  This introduction they give includes describing what a technician is expecting to see and know and introduces the basic hardware setup.  Every certified professional should be familiar with most of the concept introduced in this episode.
episodes.title: Introduction to Cisco Hardware

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and continue with the hardware introduction but now focusing on on the interfaces and how they are named.  They describe some of the network modules, WICS, HWICS and EHWICS.  With that basic introduction to the hardware done, the guys show how to start a basic configuration on a cisco router.  Don shows us what happens and describes the information displayed when a router or switch is powered on.  They list the basic software and additional equipment needed to connect to the router.
episodes.title: Introduction to Cisco Hardware Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don begin working with the command line interface (CLI) to the Cisco Internetwork Operating System (IOS).  They introduce the interface and demonstrate how to navigate through the commands and demonstrate several of the commands.  The guys emphasize a working familiarity and comfort for the CCENT candidate with the CLI they will be expected to have before sitting for the exam.  Practice is key!
episodes.title: Introduction to the IOS CLI

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don show how to get Cisco device ready for a production network.  Using the CLI, they show basic configuration for access passwords and setting the clock on a device.  They discuss how important it is to set and how to configure passwords.  They also demonstrate the way to protect these passwords through the CLI.  The guys also take a look and show how to set the clock on a Cisco device to the proper time and timezone.  This time configuration is important for synchronizing logs across multiple devices within your management domain.
episodes.title: Initial Device Configuration

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don continue with the initial device configuration using the CLI.  They demonstrate how to setup a cisco device for management not only from the console but also for remote access as well.  The guys demonstrate the access connection using password protection and telnet access.  This is configuration that is necessary for management access from across multiple networks.
episodes.title: Initial Device Configuration Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don continue with configuring stronger security access.  They demonstrate configuring SSH and AAA new-model (local database) for a stronger security than just password security.  Don also shows how to generate a new digital certificate for security use.
episodes.title: Initial Device Configuration Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don introduce LAN Switching.  They discuss the basics of layer 2 switching concepts: the basic differences between a hub (layer 1) and switch (layer 2).  The way switches build the mac address table and how switches forward unicasts and broadcasts.  Using a switch, Don demonstrates how the switch builds mac address table and the show commands that reveal that table.
episodes.title: LAN Switching

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don show how to create and work with VLANs.  The guys talk about how to segment a switch using VLANs.  They demonstrate how to create VLANs and assign ports into VLANs.  On a switch, you can create data VLANsand voice VLANs.  Even though a single port cannot be part of 2 data VLANs; a single port can be in a data VLAN and a voice VLAN at the same time, Don shows us.
episodes.title: VLANs

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don show how to create a consistent layer 2 environment with multiple switches by using layer 2 trunking.  They demonstrate how to configure both ISL and 802.1q trunking and how to verify trunking is working.  They also emphasize the need and use of trunks to allow for multiple VLANs to communicate across multiple switches.
episodes.title: VLANs Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don continue with some advanced VLANs management using VTP (VLAN Trunking Protocol).  They discuss the purpose and show how to configure VTP across multiple switches.  Using VTP they show how VLAN configuration propagate across multiple switches.  The guys demonstrate not only enabling VTP but the different VTP modes: Server, Client and Transparent.
episodes.title: VLANs Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don continue to show how to work with multiple switches and multiple VLANs efficiently.  They introduce the idea of VTP pruning.  They show how this prevents sending VLAN traffic to switches that do not have any active ports in those VLANs.  The guys take  a moment to explain how this optimizes bandwidth usage across trunk links.
episodes.title: VLANs Part 4

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don show how to use Layer 2 discovery protocols.  CDP and LLDP are two protocols used.   They configure and discuss the usage of both protocols.  CDP is Cisco proprietary and LLDP is open standard and works with non Cisco equipment.  These discovery protocols work with devices that support either or both of these protocols.  The guys also show how to discover machines connected to Cisco switches by using the ARP and mac address table.
episodes.title: Layer 2 Discovery Protocols

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don introduce layer 2 security concepts.  They talk about the need for it and how to configure it.  Even though there are other more complex methods (802.1x), the guys start with the basics and configuration of port security.  They talk about how to put a limit on the number of mac addresses each port will allow to connect.  Don and Ronnie show the default settings of port configuration and show how to manipulate and change the default settings to get port security working exactly how you may need to work.
episodes.title: Port Security

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don review the basic routing concepts.  They review the routing basics.  The guys discuss how a router builds its routing table through directly connected routes, static assignments and routing protocols.  Routing protocols are the preferred method when you have multiple routers and there are many advantages to using them, they explain.   Don and Ronnie also take a few moments to describe the difference between Distance Vector and Link State Protocols too.   Lastly, they mention how a cisco router deals with the possibility of multiple routes to the same destination from multiple protocols by using Administrative Distance—the trustworthiness of a route protocol and the load balancing that can occur if  multiple routes have the same metric.
episodes.title: Routing Protocols

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don show basic routing between connected networks and interfaces on a router.  They explain that routing normally requires  moving traffic between 2 networks on different interfaces.  To route traffic to different networks residing off the same interfaces requires configuring sub interfaces and trunks.  This is used when we need Inter-VLAN Routing.  They show how to configure the switch and the router to do the inter-VLAN routing.
episodes.title: Router on a Stick

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don show how to manually configure routes that are not directly connected.  They show this configuration is great for controlling the routing table but it also drawbacks too.  These include poor scalability and unidirectional routing according according to guys.  Don also configure how to prefer one static route over another by implementing a higher administrative distance.
episodes.title: Static Routes

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don show how to configure default routes and floating static routes.  The guys show the need to configure a default route.  This is a route in our routing table for any route that doesn’t match any other route in the table that can be configured.  They also show configuring a back up static route in the possibility that a dynamic route may fail.  This is called a floating static route.  This allows you maintain a static route without it overwriting the current dynamic route unless that dynamic route fails.
episodes.title: Static Routes Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don introduce the distance vector protocol of RIP, routing information protocol.  This protocol is a good protocol to start learning how dynamic protocols work.  They discuss metric of hop count and the pitfall of distance vector routing, routing loops.  The guys introduce max hop count, split horizon and poison reverse as technology that can prevent routing loops.
episodes.title: Routing Information Protocol

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don show how to configure and verify implementing RIP.  They show configuring both RIP and RIPv2 and discuss the differences.  They also show how to verify not only RIP operations and routing but debugging and timers as well.
episodes.title: Routing Information Protocol Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don show how to configure DHCP as a service running on the router.  They discuss briefly the DHCP process and demonstrate how to configure a DHCP server on the router along with options.  The guys also show how to configure a router interface to get an address from cisco dhcp server and how to setup options—additional information that can be handed out with dhcp
episodes.title: Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don show how to configure a Cisco router as a NTP server and NTP client.  They discuss the importance of NTP for networking devices.  The guys show the commands to configure a Cisco router as a NTP master and client.  They also show how to verify the configuration.
episodes.title: Network Time Protocol

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don introduce Standard Access Control Lists (ACL).  They show it’s configuration and discuss it’s usage.  The guys discuss how to configure them logically first to help us to understand how they work.  They also emphasize that we can create standard numbered ACLs or named ACLs.  With the numbered ACLs, it is not easy to edit a misconfiguration—entire list must be removed, then recreated and applied, according to the guys.  With the named ACLs, it allows you to edit the ACLs entries easily.  The demonstrate the syntax on configuring it on the router.
episodes.title: Access Control Lists

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don continue with Access Control Lists (ACL).  They move behind talking about the theory of the configuration to configuring it on a router and verifying it working too.  They also take the time to discuss some of the configuration pitfalls. The guys remind us to check the configuration and several details you need to master before CCENT.
episodes.title: Access Control Lists Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don explain a fairly universal technology called Network Address Translation.  This technology has help slow down the consumption of the IPv4 address space on the internet by translating one address into another ip address.  There are 3 methods:  Static NAT, Dynamic NAT and Port Address Translation (PAT) also called NAT Overload, according to the guys.  They describe how NAT works and then show the configuration of Static NAT, a one to one translation.
episodes.title: Network Address Translation

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don continue with configuring NAT.  They show how to configure Dynamic NAT and PAT (or NAT Overload). They discuss the use case scenario of both configurations, how to configure it and  how to verify it’s operation on a router.  The guys show why PAT is the most often used in networks.
episodes.title: Network Address Translation Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don show us some of the maintenance task that a Cisco Profession must understand and configure, specifically setting up a remote syslog server. They talk about reason to configure it and demonstrates the it’s configuration and then show the output.  This, the guys point out, is essential to provide solid information for troubleshooting and maintaining multiple Cisco devices.
episodes.title: Device Management

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don continue with additional maintenance task of backing up routing configurations to a remote server.  This primary task, they demonstrate, helps to insure that the configuration is saved in the event of equipment failure or misconfigurations. They also show some of the pitfalls of configuration restorations that can occur if not careful.
episodes.title: Device Management Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don show us the basic device security that every cisco technician should know how to configure: using passwords, limiting access to ssh and using access-list to control access to the router.  The use of passwords is just the first step to implementing basic security, the guys tell us. They also talk about setting up username/password to provide authentication and password protection.  Don and Ronnie also discuss the importance of limiting access using SSH only and using an access-list to control access by source ip address.  They also mention that when applying the standard ACL to the VTY line you must use access-class apply.
episodes.title: Device Security

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don show some of details about working with the CiscoIOS.  They show how to know about CiscoIOS updates and how to best use that information.  Don and Ronnie also show how to update the router IOS.  They also take a look at some commands to see the amount of RAM and storage available for the CiscoIOS.  These basic maintenance duties are part of every Cisco technician’s skill set.
episodes.title: Device Maintenance

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don continue with device maintenance duties by show the completion of the IOS update.  Before completing the updates process, they guys also discuss not only updating the IOS to the router but also verifying the integrity of the file uploaded and setting the new IOS os the boot system image.  Along with this updating, they also demonstrate how to do a password recovery with setting the configuration register to do so.
episodes.title: Device Maintenance Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don take us through the Cisco Troubleshooting Model that every CCENT candidate need to understand before the exam and also show an additional methodology using the OSI model to help isolate and resolve networking issues.  They also show the use of traceroute and pings when troubleshooting connectivity issues.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Tools

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don continue with some additional troubleshooting using advanced pings and demonstrate the use of debugs.  They show a couple of different examples of how to change the pings to make it more useful in troubleshooting.  They also remind us about the importance of using the undebug all commands.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Tools Part 2
